title: We know about the Statute of limitations for medical debt is 4 years, how do we use this as a defense exactly?
question: If we have not paid or agreed to pay disputed charges on medical debt for over 4 years, what are we to do next? We passed the SOL and we want to know what are our rights and/or defense with the SOL? What do we tell or say to creditor or service providers who ask for payments after said SOL has passed?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Filing a lawsuit,Motion to dismiss
answers:
Here's a sample answer to a debt collection lawsuit: http://www.karlinlaw.com/blog/2012/06/sample-general-denial-answer-filed-in-california-buisness-or-real-estate-lawsuit-with-affirmative-de.shtml

The state of limitations is an affirmative defense that you must allege in prove if sued.
You are not required to take any action until a claim is brought against you. At that time, you can raise the statute of limitations as an affirmative defense against their claim.

If you are being sued, you must plead the statute of limitations as an affirmative defense in your answer to the complaint. Thereafter, you either file a motion for summary judgment, or you go to trial and prove that the debt is more than four years old. If you are not being sued, it may be a violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act for a debt collector to attempt to collect the debt (especially if it has no intention of filing suit).
You can even make a motion to dismiss the statute of limitations grounds and tried in the litigation at the beginning or place that is an affirmative defense in your answer to the complaint
